segments.text: I think that one thing that I probably regret would be not really appreciating the
a black perspective in the early 1960s.
And not appreciating it simply because I was taught the Hmong culture and I was
I wasn't believing that.
I didn't have the passion for it.
I really didn't appreciate it.
So I guess what I'm saying is that I regret that I didn't have the appreciation that I have now.
And really, the genuine sensitivity, which I thank God for, really torn another really minority
And we're all minority people one way or another, somewhere along the line.
And just really caring for people.
And I think when God comes into your life, he gives you the kind of love.
You can care for your brother, whether he's a darker brother or a lighter brother.
You can care for him.
As far as doing something different, I've got to say...
That when you're dealing with people, let me give you an example of what I'm talking about.
When I went with my first church in Alabama, it was in Dauphin, Alabama.
It was in 1974.
One of the previous ministers in that church was there from, say, 1966 to 1968, something like that.
And...
He was a graduate of Union Theological Seminary.
It's a liberal seminary in the Southern Presbyterian Church.
And he, this was right in the height of the Civil Rights Movement.
He had the March of Washington.
This guy stood up in the pulpit for these people from Southern Alabama.
So many of them are from the rural background.
And he declares in the book that he really shouldn't be in the book.
He really ought to be out there marching in the streets with the civil rights movement.
And that is really the gospel.
And that guy represented the liberal Christianity.
The gospel is changing social institutions.
His approach
was revolutionary.
He grew that church from 130 to 66.
What did he accomplish?
I came in in 1970.
I was there until 1977.
And we saw the church grow.
We also saw the church grow in a
spiritually in terms of race relationships.
But it was an evolution.
We're trying to help people understand what God is saying in His Word to people.
And what does that say about how you live your life?
So in the sense of taking an evolutionary approach instead of a revolutionary approach, I think that was a good thing.
I do not regret that at all.
Let me mention that.
No, I think that's about as specific as I can be.
How much?
How much of an impact did the Civil Rights Movement have?
Well, let me mention, I think this is interesting.
This concerns a church that I know that was in the PCA, and this was probably in maybe the early 80s, and this particular church had adopted in the
coming out of the Civil Rights Movement.
They've adopted post-war monarchy.
This was a church that was in the South.
And this church, even in the mid-1970s, this particular congregation in the South, had some officers that stood out in front of the church and turned, and turned backs.
And some people were coming in, because there was all that people.
And the, and this policy continued.
Now that, my understanding is that those people took some heat.
Some of those people, some of those leaders took some heat from their children, who were adults.
Wasn't the worst thing.
And,
I think in the early 1980s, this church went through a review of that policy.

And the thing that's really interesting about it, just to show you how God can work, the people that did the review of that were the very people, some of whom had been involved in establishing that policy in the very beginning.
And they were some of the very people who had been around in the mid-1970s.
and re-debated that issue and turned away those people of courage.
They continued to hold on to the policy of keeping the border.
They re-studied that issue.
They went through kind of a bondless question and they voted to do away with that policy.
So in many cases, it's not what you do, but the way you go about doing it.
And God just kind of had prepared.
He kind of worked to prepare.
But you see, you've got certain...
certain folks who can't be patient.
It's got to be now.
And they want a war, and there's got to be a revolution.
That took, let's say, that took from 1965 to the early 1990s for that change to happen.
And even then when that changed, not everybody agreed.
But you've got to understand, the median age
So I think that to me is an illustration of the best way to approach this.
Is there anything else that you would like to say?
Well, I can remember that on one occasion somebody shared with me a paper that had been written by a conservative pastor
probably back in the 1960s, in which he was trying to present a biblical basis for segregation.
And as I sat down and read through the paper, I was aghast at the incredible misinterpretation and misuse of the scripture in order to justify a cultural position.
And I can understand that.

I think there's a danger that whenever we come to the Scriptures that there's a danger, always the danger, that we will want to bend the Scripture to our cultural bias instead of us being directed and corrected by the Scripture.
So I guess that would just be one thing I would say is that I believe the Scripture is the ultimate thorn in our life.
And that we need to constantly and prayerfully work at, in the process of interpretation, that we're not trying to make the Scripture fit in with our own bias.
That we really are being challenged and corrected and directed by the Scripture in our attitudes and our approach to culture.
There is nothing else, and that finishes it.

Well, Mark, I really appreciate this opportunity, and I hope that as this gets added to the growing body of oral tapes and oral history department at Texas A&M, I hope this will be of help in terms of scholarship and research for people in years to come.
We surely appreciate it.
You're very welcome.
